items.title: No time to warn or to prepare: Natimuk met the fire of our future
items.description: The anatomy of the Natimuk fire offers a glimpse into a new and faster kind of bushfire — and the growing vulnerability of communities as climate change fuels dangerous conditions.

items.title: What Israel does now about Iran will be crucial
items.description: Israel joining with other countries in the Middle East to press Donald Trump not to launch a military strike against a weakened Iran is something that would have seemed incomprehensible even a couple of years ago.

items.title: Why Xi Jinping keeps an Iran conflict at arm's length
items.description: Xi Jinping's ambition is to occupy a central position in a reshaped international system, not to lead a permanent grouping of sanctioned or crisis-prone states.

items.title: Rain, cyclone threat and heatwave: Weekend of weather hazards across Australia
items.description: January is the middle of Australia's severe weather season and a multitude of hazards are emerging across the country this weekend.

items.title: Trump threatens tariffs on countries who oppose US Greenland takeover
items.description: The US president insists America needs to acquire the territory of NATO partner Denmark for national security reasons.

items.title: Australian who escaped Iran says the protests — and the crackdown — are 'different this time'
items.description: On a visit to his home town outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

items.title: Son of Iran's late shah says regime 'will fall' and vows to return
items.description: Reza Pahlavi says the mass protests which have gripped the country will topple the regime and has called for the international community to intervene.

items.title: British dual citizens fear missing family trips as passport rules change
items.description: From February 25, dual citizens of the UK and Ireland will be required to enter the UK using a valid British or Irish passport, a change causing major headaches for dual citizens with imminent travel plans.

items.title: Lance Armstong destroyed his legacy with five monosyllabic answers to Oprah
items.description: Lance Armstrong had successfully doped for years. But when the evidence backed him into a corner he took control of the narrative and confessed live on Oprah's couch, martyring himself to cycling's EPO era.

items.title: Tim Picton's alleged attacker accused of another assault, posting it on Snapchat
items.description: The man accused of assaulting former Labor strategist Tim Picton allegedly knocked another man unconscious two days prior.

items.title: Nikita Tszyu accuses Zefara of quitting after grudge match called off
items.description: Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa hotly anticipated fight is abandoned after the second round as the crowd vents its frustration at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre.

items.title: How to talk to your children about the allegations against author Craig Silvey
items.description: A prominent parenting expert says serious allegations made against one of Australia’s most renowned authors should spark difficult but important conversations in households across the country.

items.title: Singer Julio Iglesias denies sexually assaulting two former employees
items.description: The Spanish recording artist is accused of sexually and physically assaulting two women who worked at his residences in the Dominican Republic and the Bahamas between January and October 2021.

items.title: Former South Korean president jailed over martial law declaration
items.description: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol is sentenced to five years in jail over crimes relating to his failed attempt at imposing martial law in the country.

items.title: 50/50 quiz: Test your knowledge of The Neverending Story, cocktails and 90s lyrics
items.description: Every question has only two options: One is right and the other is wrong. You have an even chance of guessing correctly each time.

items.title: Khalid Abdalla protested during the Arab Spring. He has a message for 2026
items.description: The Crown star Khalid Abdalla is in Australia to perform his play Nowhere at Sydney Festival, exploring his experience on the frontline of the Arab Spring in Egypt.

items.title: Why this Olympian is proud to be a gay role model despite trolling
items.description: Campbell Harrison was homophobically trolled in the lead-up to the Paris Olympics. It strengthened his conviction about the importance of visible queer role models in sport.

items.title: Japan wants to mine the seabed at a depth of 6 kilometres for one reason: China
items.description: Tokyo hopes the plan to mine as much as 16 million tonnes of rare earths will help reduce its reliance on China, but will it work?

items.title: Children in Ukraine risk hypothermia after Russian attacks, aid groups say
items.description: International aid agencies say children across Ukraine risk hypothermia in freezing temperatures as emergency stocks of power generators run low following Russian attacks on energy infrastructure.

items.title: Top faith leaders urge PM to scrap new racial hatred offence
items.description: A broad of coalition of Australia's most influential religious leaders have urged the prime minister to scrap Labor's proposal to outlaw the promotion of racial hatred.

items.title: Can Machado actually transfer the Nobel Peace Prize to Trump?
items.description: While it can be gifted, refused or displayed, the Nobel Peace Prize itself — once awarded — belongs to its original recipient forever.

items.title: Foreign fishing vessel filmed 100m away from Queensland coast
items.description: Locals on Queensland's far north tip have shared their account after seeing an Indonesian fishing boat within a stone's throw of the mainland.

items.title: Once top secret, Greenland's only US military base is stirring trouble
items.description: Here is what we know about the US military footprint in Greenland, and how the increase of troops from Denmark and its allies stacks up.

items.title: Cars floating out to sea, campers fleeing: Is this all climate change in action?
items.description: When it comes to extreme rainfall, it is hard for climate scientists to say what's natural and what's caused by climate change. But they do know the most extreme events are dropping more rain, more often. This is why.

items.title: Engaged Aussie tennis stars qualify for Open within an hour of each other
items.description: Maddison Inglis and Jason Kubler were able to celebrate their Australian Open qualifications together in a heartwarming moment.
